metadata.case_name: Basant Chandra Ghose v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Province of Bihar and Orissa formed in 1911; Bengal Municipal Act of 1884 applied to whole province; Patna City under Patna City Municipality created under Bengal Act.
Patna Administration Act of 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915) passed to create new municipality for area called Patna Administration; came into force on 5th January 1916.

Section 3(1)(f) empowered Local Government to extend provisions of Bengal Municipal Act 1884 to Patna (Administration area) subject to restrictions and modifications; Section 5 allowed cancellation or modification of orders under s.3; Section 6(b) allowed inclusion of local areas in vicinity.
Local Government created Patna Administration Committee and extended certain sections of Bengal Municipal Act to Patna Administration area via notifications.
Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act 1922 (Act VII of 1922) enacted, repealing Bengal Municipal Act 1884; applied to Patna City but not to Patna Administration area.
Patna Administration Amendment Act 1928 (Act IV of 1928) amended 1915 Act; s.4 deemed sections of Bengal Act continued until cancelled.
Notification dated 25th April 1931 (No. 4594 L.S.G.) cancelled previous notifications, extended selected and modified sections of 1922 Act to Patna Administration area, omitting ss.4,5,6,84,104.
Constitution of India came into force on 26th January 1950; powers of Local Government transferred to Governor of Bihar.
Area called Patna Village adjoined Patna Administration area and began to be built upon.
Notification No. MVP-45/50-3645 L.S.G. dated 11th April 1951 published 18th April 1951 under s.6(b) including Patna Village area within Patna (under Patna Administration Committee).

Notification No. M AI-201-51-406 L.S.G. dated 23rd April 1951 extended modified s.104 of 1922 Act to Patna Administration and Patna Village areas, allowing levy of taxes from beginning of quarter next to assessment completion.

Appellant (Secretary of Rate Payers Association, Patna) and members reside in Patna Village area, originally outside municipal limits, brought within on 18th April 1951 and subjected to taxes for 1st April 1951 to 31st March 1952.

High Court of Patna in MJC No. 78 of 1952 on 22nd December 1952 granted leave to appeal under Art 132(1) Constitution, held impugned sections and notifications intra vires applying In re Delhi Laws Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of Patna Administration Act 1915 permit delegated legislation and are ultra vires.
Whether notifications dated 25th April 1931, 18th April 1951, and 23rd April 1951 under the Act are ultra vires.
Scope of delegation under s.3(1)(f) post Delhi Laws Act case, including power to select sections, modify, and whether modifications can alter policy.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notifications are delegated legislation and bad; sections 3(1)(f) and 5 of 1915 Act which permit delegation are ultra vires.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned sections and notifications are intra vires.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: In re Delhi Laws Act (1951 SCR 747)

court_reasoning.text: Notification of 25th April 1931 does not affect petitioner as limited to Patna Administration area, not Patna Village.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner cannot challenge as it does not affect him.

court_reasoning.text: Analyzed Delhi Laws Act case: majority upheld delegation to apply existing/future laws with restrictions/modifications not altering essential features or policy; modifications limited to minor changes for local adaptation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Essential legislative function (policy determination) cannot be delegated.

court_reasoning.text: Notification of 23rd April 1951 ultra vires as modified s.104 bypasses ss.4,5,6 of 1922 Act requiring hearing of objections before imposing tax, altering essential policy of statutory guarantee.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Changes policy by disregarding Legislature's mandate on objections.

court_reasoning.text: Section 3(1)(f) intra vires as it allows picking sections of 1922 Act and minor modifications, akin to applying part of Act upheld in Delhi Laws and Burah's case, provided no essential change or policy alteration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Picking section is modification but must not evade limits on essential changes.

court_reasoning.text: No need to examine s.5 as no action under it affects appellant.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(f) of Patna Administration Act 1915 is intra vires provided restrictions and modifications do not effect essential changes or alter policy.
Notification dated 23rd April 1951 is ultra vires as it travels beyond s.3(1)(f) by altering policy of 1922 Act.

precedents_cited.relevance: Elaborate analysis on validity of delegation, application of laws with modifications; limits on altering policy.
Upheld applying part of an Act; picking sections akin to this.

statutes_cited.name: Patna Administration Act, 1915 (Bihar and Orissa Act I of 1915)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned for permitting delegation; s.3(1)(f) held intra vires with limits; used for notifications.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar and Orissa Municipal Act, 1922 (Bihar and Orissa Act VII of 1922)
statutes_cited.relevance: Sections extended/modified; ss.4-6 provide policy of hearing objections before taxation; modified s.104 bypassed this.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Municipal Act, 1884
statutes_cited.relevance: Sections previously extended to Patna Administration; repealed 1922 but deemed continued until 1931.

statutes_cited.name: Patna Administration (Amendment) Act, 1928 (Bihar and Orissa Act IV of 1928)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended 1915 Act; s.4 deemed continuation of Bengal Act sections.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Leave to appeal granted by High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds; s.3(1)(f) of 1915 Act held intra vires with restrictions on modifications; notification of 23rd April 1951 held ultra vires; no decision on 1931 notification or s.5 due to lack of impact on appellant.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that notification dated 23rd April 1951 is ultra vires

key_quotes.text: The power to restrict and modify does not import the power to make essential changes. It is confined to alterations of a minor character such as are necessary to make an Act intended for one area applicable to another.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits on 'modification' from Delhi Laws Act analysis.

key_quotes.text: To alter the essential character of an Act or to change it in material particulars is to legislate, and that, namely the power to legislate, all authorities are agreed, cannot be delegated by a Legislature which is not unfettered.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on non-delegation of essential legislative functions.

key_quotes.text: one of its essential features is that no municipality competent to tax shall be thrust upon a locality without giving its inhabitants a chance of being heard and of being given an opportunity to object.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Identifies policy in ss.4-6 of 1922 Act bypassed by notification.
